Name: Playing With Fire
Description:
A fun, fast paced, dice and card game of risk and chance where the highest scoring player wins the game.  Players roll the dice in an attempt to score points on each roll in order to score a Blaze and earn bonus points.  Special cards offer opportunity for additional challenges and surprises that can push you over the top, or you could get burnt and lose it all.
 Suitable for in-person or virtual play for 2 or more players.
Optional betting and tournament rules offer additional fun and variety. Will you play it safe, or are you willing to play with fire in order to win?

—description from the publisher

Name: Kingdom Rush: Elemental Uprising – Gnomish Gnonsense Expansion
Description:
A Gnome Wizard, boom-bunnies, and a lumbering ragdoll of doom! What's not to love as you encounter four new scenarios of magic and trickery leading to the imposing colossal lizard boss Xyzzy!

Inside the expansion, you’ll find the new Hero Razz & Rags alongside the massive 80mm tall new Boss Xyzzy!

Across four scenarios you’ll encounter new mechanics including Gnome Trickster Tower Mods, new Miniboss the Gnoll Warleaders, and the gigantic hammers of Xyzzy!

—description from the publisher

Name: Kingdom Rush: Elemental Uprising – More Than Shadows Expansion
Description: More Than Shadows Expansion contains unlocked Stretch Goals from the Elemental Uprising Gamefound campaign. Specifically, this expansions includes two new heroes, two new bosses, and seven new scenarios.

Name: グッドプライス！ (Good Price!)
Description:
ã‚°ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒ—ãƒ©ã‚¤ã‚¹ï¼ (Good Price!) is a communication game from Japan. Players are business planners trying to bring together new products to sell on a TV shopping network. They must keep the products in a price range, and get them approved by the company chairperson.

The game has a deck of 52 Material cards, each quartile shows a product type, such as fish, futon, suit, song, curry.

The other decks have a variety of price info, from 100s to millions of Yen. There are numbered cards for voting and ranking cards, #1 marked as 'Chairman'.

The game has paper and pencils so players can write out their ideas. Once the products have been discussed, players vote on them, and the winning ideas get scoring chips.
user summary

Name: Spank the Monkey (Second Edition)
Description:
Spank the Monkey is a fast-paced, humorous card game with sneaky tactics. All players are working in a junk yard where a teasing monkey has appeared. Your job is to climb up to the monkey and spank it.

There are 5 types of cards in the game. Junk cards, like the totem pole, surfboard, and garden gnome, are used to pile on top of each other and form the "board" in front of each player. Each junk card has its own height, strength, and often a special ability when played. The combined height of your junk cards is used to see if you have reached the monkey. Some junk cards are a bit fragile, but they can be strengthened by reinforcement cards like duct tape, ivy, and a hired security guard. Each junk card also belongs to at least one category of which there are 7 in the game.

During the game, you attack the junk card of other players in an attempt to make them fall down, or at least lower them a bit. There are three kind of attacks; throwing attacks (bowling ball, flock of seagulls, and dynamite) that you can use on any junk card, hand attacks (chainsaw, blind, and crowbar) that you can only use on cards at the same height as yourself, and the sneak attacks (lawyer, wasp’s nest, and ball cannon) that all have special abilities.

A die roll is used to solve the attack. You add the attack value of your attack card and compare it to the combined strength of the attacked junk card and any reinforcement cards it might have. The defending player may play defense cards that either lower the die roll (umbrella, satellite dish, and wok) or completely stop or redirect the attack (electric force field, tennis racket, and trampoline).

If a junk card is destroyed, you have effectively lowered that player's height by the height of the card, and if there are junk cards above the destroyed card, they fall down, and the defender is forced to make a collision roll to see if the junk cards also are destroyed.

The fifth card type is called special, and it is a kind of catchall for all the crazy special effect you may do in the game. There are all kinds of tricks, like giving you an extra turn, starting an earthquake, and having a police raid.

NOTE: The expansion Monkey Business has been included in the base game since 2007.

Name: 舞妓ジャングル (Maiko Jungle)
Description:
This is an irregular sugoroku game for two players who are trying to get to the goal before their opponents in Kyoto, which has suddenly turned into a jungle.

It's sugoroku, but without dice.

When you move forward, you reveal all of your cards to your opponent. If the cards in your hand meet the requirements of the next square (e.g., you have a "5" in your hand, two red cards, etc.), you can advance to the next square.

If you can create a hand that can meet the conditions of multiple squares, you can advance to several squares at once in one turn.
It's hard to decide whether you should have all the cards in your hand and move forward at once or chop them up into small pieces.

Since the sugoroku squares are cards, the board changes every time you play, and the best way to make the best hand changes every time, so you can play with a fresh mind as often as you like.

In addition, each card is a real-life jungle of tourist attractions in Kyoto (Kyoto Tower, Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine, etc.).
It is also fun to see the beautiful maiko pieces you use strutting around the exotic Kyoto.

The game takes about 15 minutes per game, and is a game for two players that can be played easily while worrying.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Name: Snowsmash Clan
Description:
As the director of a winter sport called "Snow Smash", you lead three clan members to compete against rival teams.

Players use two actions, "Step" and "Smash", to move around the field, which becomes narrower with time, and send snowballs to predict the whereabouts of opponents hiding somewhere in the same field.

If the snowball hits, you get points!
Use the unique smash gadgets called "Arum" to get more points than your rivals!
As the director of a winter sport called "Snow Smash", you lead three clan members to compete against rival teams.

Players use two actions, "Step" and "Smash", to move around the field, which becomes narrower with time, and send snowballs to predict the whereabouts of opponents hiding somewhere in the same field.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Name: Pass the Deck: A party starting drinking game
Description:
Pass the Deck is a fun party-starting, friend-making, villain creating drinking game.
How to Play: Players compete in various mini-games like "naming Disney movies" and "having a strip off". The goal of the game is to be the first person to win 3 Golden Beer cards.

Unique Game Play: Secret Cards are kept secret until someone unknowingly completes the action on the card ("Next person to use the restroom drinks"), and Rule Cards which force you to do something ("Grab drinks for anyone that needs one until the end of the game").

Includes 112 unique cards, 13 blank cards for your own hilarious ideas, and a koozie for the winner (to remind the others who the ? is).

Perfect for tailgating, college parties, 21 runs, bachelor/bachelorette parties, camping, pre-funking / pre-gaming, white elephant / secret Santa gift for those that love drinking games.

Name: Everyone's a Critic: A game of drawing sketchy things
Description:
Everyone’s A Critic is a fun adult drawing game that brings artists and amateurs together to compete for the most hilarious drawing.
     HOW TO PLAY: Players take turns as “The Critic”. The Critic draws a card and reads it out loud. The other players have 60 seconds to draw the best image that comes to mind. The first player to win three rounds wins it all. Players: 3 - 10+ | Time: 30 - 90 min | Ages: 17+
     Some of the drawings will be lighthearted like draw your spirit animal, others will be sketchy (pun intended) like draw the person most likely to fart during sex.


There are five card types: Draw This, Questions, Eyes Closed, Speed Round, and Wild Cards.

     The game includes 170 sketchy drawing prompts, 10 blank cards for your own ridiculous ideas, 10 draw pads, 10 pencils, a sand timer, and a pair of very stylish glasses?


—description from the publisher

Name: 1822 Scotland Medium Regional and North Regional scenario board set
Description:
This is an reduced map used for the 1822: Railways of Great Britain game, which is part of the 18xx series based on the growth of the Railways through the age of steam. It is the northern part of the 1822 map, that is Birmingham and northwards, with Wales and London as off board locatons.

Players take the part of investors in Railway companies and then operate the companies to maximise their own wealth.

The basic rules of 1822 is used with just some small changes. The setup is different, removing some privates, minors, majors and tiles, which results in a slightly shorter game.

Privates used in 1822NRS: P1-P21, except P5, P10, P17

Minors used in 1822NRS: 1-10, 15, 16, 26-29

Majors removed from 1822NRS: GWR, LBSCR, SECR, and SWR

The rules are available on the publisher's site.

Name: Vengeance of the Gods
Description:
The world burns with divine wrath in a new sacred war. Test your mettle in Vengeance of the Gods, where modern warfare meets the power of the ancient gods in a challenging area control strategy wargame. Choose one of 12 ancient deities to worship, each one granting unique and powerful abilities. Master the skies with the might of Zeus or fool your enemy with one of Loki's mischievous tricks. With the gods on your side, it's a race against other players for territory and resources and you fight to rule the world. Will you dominate your enemies and prove you divine right or will you fall before the might of other deities?

Theme:
Modern warfare with ancient gods.

Game-play:
Each player builds a modern army (soldiers, artillery, tanks, planes) while also worshipping an ancient god. When the gods are happy they grant players powerful abilities to help them wage war.

Battles are conducted using dice. The game comes with 30 dice so large battles are conducted quickly.

Goal:
Each player starts the game with a town. For short games (60-120mins) the first player to take control of 3 towns wins.

For longer conquest game (120-180mins) the first player to control 4 continents wins.

—description from the designer

Name: Calling of the Matriarch
Description:
"Calling of the Matriarch" is a premium print-and-play, narrative-focused, fully cooperative 1-4 Players Role-Playing Adventure Board Game.

The game takes place in a grimmer aspect of the fantasy world Spheria, as you create a character and assume the role of an adventurer trying to survive an outbreak of monsters in the once-thriving city of the Kingdom.

You, "The Sojourner", takes refuge with the city's survivors in a haven known as "The Lith", guided by a mysterious figure known as The Matriarch, you go on dangerous quests into the monster-ridden city, alone, or together with your ally, to overcome challenges that may bring you closer to you and the other's ultimate survival, and at the same time, seek the truth of the event by acquiring information and hints throughout your many quests.

Inspired by role-playing games and dungeon crawl games of deep storytelling, adventure, and dynamic combat, as well as skirmish games with miniatures, "Calling of the Matriarch" is both a solo and cooperative game with no need of any adversary players. You may venture into the danger as a lone adventurer to create their own legend, or together with their ally, carve their way through many events and dangers to reveal the hidden truth behind the crisis.

Name: シャオパイロン (Xiao Pylon)
Description:
ã‚·ãƒ£ã‚ªãƒ‘ã‚¤ãƒ­ãƒ³ (Xiao Pylon) å°ç™½é¾ (Small White Dragon) is a game from Japan with players trying to collect scales from a dragon by entertainment.

The dragon starts in the middle of the chequered board and the players' tokens set up near the dragon. Players then use hand cards to see who moves, and try to get their token next to the dragon to collect scale tokens. Then a card is turned up to move the dragon. The board is wrap around, and the dragon can move diagonally, but not onto a player.

The game uses a butting mechanism. Players chose a card in secret, reveal together, and when cards are matched, those players cancel each other out. The highest clear number wins, but players also have fan cards. If a high number wins, a fan card can also move. But if multiple fan cards are played, they also cancel each other.

After 6 rounds, the player with the most scales is the winner.

The game includes rules for 2 players.
user summary

The publisher says:
An old story. The scales of the White Dragon were very beautiful and highly prized. However, it is said that anything that touches the body of the White Dragon will be cursed and unhappy. You have found the temple where the White Dragon lives. A small white dragon lived in the temple. Then Hakuryu spoke to me. "Do you want scales? If so, entertain me. By the way, scales are swelling. Who is the most daring and lucky one in the swelling? Then, the color of your eyes changed and the battle for scales began. Who can get the most scales?

The simple rule is that the person who collects the scales and wins the most in all 6 rounds, but the card selection for each round is very troublesome, and the tricky moving small white dragon determines the outcome of the game. An unusual card butting game that uses square boards and pieces.
publisher's summary

Name: Crazy Cultists: The Dark Powers Expansion
Description:
You wanted dark powers...and now you got 'em! Or at least you CAN get them. Earn the Dark One's favor to be granted powerful new abilities in the form of Dark Powers Cards and start wreakin' some freakin' havoc!
â€‹
Adds 13 unique and super-powerful Hijinx Cards that are used to thoroughly fracture your opponents' favor with the Dark One.

—description from the publisher

Name: iDOL ST@GE BATTLE 765基本セット
Description:
Form a unit of three up and coming idols from 765 Production and aim to have as many fans as possible by the time the final stage comes around. Form a deeper bond with your unit as a producer by winning stages and completing jobs. Luck is important in this competitive industry. Stage and job cards require stat check rolls according to the affection of your idols. If you succeed, they are added to your deck and often raise your idols' affection. When their affection reaches its maximum level they become awakened, upgrading to more powerful stats and effects.

Winning stages is a battle between producers attempting to have the most appeal. In turn order, players select one of three stages they would like to participate in for the round. From left to right the stages are resolved, allowing players to play as many cards with the appeal keyword as possible from their hand to gain appeal according to their idols stats. The winner gains affection and fans, while the loser may suffer penalties. The player with the most fans by the end of the game is the winner.

Name: Nusubito
Description:
Nusubito is a two player hidden movement game in which one player will take on the role of the Thief; a ninja-like character leaping across temple rooftops in search of a hidden treasure. The other player will control the Mists, spirits who guard the temple complex.

The game is played over a series of Day and Night cycles, with three rounds per day, and one round per night.

During the day, the Thief will be secretly leaping from temple to temple looking for clues about the hidden treasure’s whereabouts, whilst the Mists spread across the board in search of the intruder!

During the night, each side will get the chance to gather resources.

Play ends when either the Thief finds the Treasure, or the Mists capture the Thief!

Name: CONFIDENT?: Mini Game
Description:
This is the mini version of the hit party game that asks questions like 'what percentage of people have dimples?'. But instead of giving exact answers, you guess with a range, aiming to get the smallest range.

Play this as a standalone game with three fun ways to play, or use it to expand the core game.

Name: Assassination in Sarajevo
Description:
A game based on the event that sparked the First World War, the assassination of the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, Franz Ferdinand, and his wife, Sofie. Utilizing die-roll and random-chit mechanics, it is designed for solitaire play but has rules for 2 players.

The game consists of two parts. In Part 1, "Assassination," the player tries to prevent the assassination or wounding of the royal couple by members of the Black Hand Serbian separatist group. In the 2-player version, one player takes the role of the Black Hand.

In Part 2, "July Crisis," the solitaire player tries to prevent the incident from starting a war; in the 2-player, one player is the peace faction, the other the war faction. The odds for peace are improved if the royal couple survived in Part 1, but that does not guarantee the "powder keg of Europe" won't explode.

This game originally appeared in World War One Illustrated magazine No. 2 and does not include the 13 six-sided dice necessary for play. Two-player rules that were not in the magazine are included in the stand-alone game.

—user summary

Name: On to Paris!
Description:
A solitaire game of the German drive on Paris in 1914, played in six turns representing the time period August 27–28 through September 6–7. The player operates the German forces and has three possible victory conditions based on army strength and unit location on the playing area at the end of the sixth turn.

German army corps move across rows of rectangles overlaid on a partial map of France (Arras to the outskirts of Paris). When German and Entente units occupy the same row of rectangles combat occurs. The player rolls 1d6 for every 2 German corps in the rectangle and adds the total result to the strength of the corps, then does the same for the Entente player. There are modifiers based on map location. Loser must retreat one row or reduce the strength of one corps. Random events may send German corps off to East Prussia or to sieges of Channel ports or Low Country towns. Other events may bring reinforcements to either side, advance the Germans’ Schlieffen Plan, result in Entente confusion or German exhaustion, etc.

This game originally appeared in World War One Illustrated magazine No. 3 and does not include the six-sided dice necessary for play. Two-player rules that were not in the magazine are included in the stand-alone game.

—user summary

Name: Connections
Description:
Based on the Granada/ITV game show that ran from 1985-1990, in which players score points by by answering general knowledge questions and make connections from letters, numbers and picture clues.

The game is divided into six rounds: Connect the Clue, Link the Letter, Find the Figure, Link the Letter, Find the Clue, and Connect the Clue.

Connect the Clue involves answering questions and figuring out the connection between the picture clues that go with them.

Link the Letter involves answering seven questions, with the first letter of each answer being placed on the board. Players win the round by unscrambling those letters and coming up with the correct word.

Find the Figure involves solving a long math equation. Again, players answer questions, with parts of the equation being placed after each answer. The first player to solve the equation wins the round.

Scoring for each round is 10 points per correct answer, and a bonus of 100 points for making the connection, except in the final round, where it’s 20 points per answer and 200 bonus points for making the connection. The player with the highest score after six rounds wins.

Name: Russia's Great War: 1914
Description:
A seven-turn game based on Russia’s invasion of East Prussia from August 17–18 through August 29–30. The Russian player wins by eliminating three German corps or by having three corps in the western end of the Western box (i.e., west of the Vistula River) and at least one corps in the other four boxes of the area-movement map. The German player’s victory requires eliminating three Russian corps and preventing any Russian units from being in the western half of the Western box.

The five movement boxes are overlaid on a map of East Prussia and a portion of the Russian Empire. Each is divided into two parts, distinguished by brown in one half and yellow in the other. Opposing units may occupy the same box without being in the same area, in which case combat is not mandatory unless the German side plays the German Reckless Advance marker. When battle occurs in the Broken Terrain of the two southern boxes each side rolls a die to limit the number of enemy corps that can participate and might further mess with an opponent by playing a Confusion marker. Other Combat and Random

Event markers include Air Recon, Cautious Advance/Pursuit, Cavalry Raid, etc. Restrictions and opportunities also arise based on individual game turns and what happened historically on the days those turns represent. A sidebar describes the historical events. (The game won an award in the Educational Board Game category at the 2019 Serious Play Conference.)

Designed to be a solitaire game published in a magazine, the stand-alone version comes with two-player rules as well. Players have to supply their own six-sided dice.

—user summary

Name: Shadows of Brimstone: Forbidden Fortress – Item Upgrades Pack #1
Description:
Items, weapons, and treasures of the Forbidden Fortress are already powerful, but these new item upgrades increase take them to the next level!

This 15-card supplement adds a collection of upgrades to enhance your items from Forbidden Fortress.

Name: Die Brücke
Description: A game with a bridge over a water bath in which players try to push each others pieces off the bridge into the water.

Name: Conocer Europa
Description:
Buy and sell, the game of the common market.
Get yourself some leather shoes in Italy, with a coal shipment from Germany and a butter shipment from Denmark. Brussels, the seat of the common market, they will give you papers so you can acquire products from every EU company.  Let's do business!

—description from the back of the box (translated

Name: Totes Emosh
Description:
Totes Emosh is basically charades with your face. You pick a card, pull the face on the card and everyone else has to guess which face you’re pulling. The player with the roundest head starts. As soon as they pull the face anyone else can shout out a guess, using the key cards to see the face numbers. Guessers can’t try again until at least one other player has had a go. No shouting “1, 2, 3, 4, 5...” you cheats. Whoever shouts out the right number wins the card. Then it’s their turn to pull a face. When all the faces have been pulled, count your cards. Most cards wins... obvs!

—description from the publisher

Name: Caracoles
Description:
Caracoles is a two player game about two snails trying to reach the yummiest food in a Japanese food festival, while avoiding the "Saltmurai". 
A playing field is set up from various tiles. Each player receives five movement cards and plays one of them in each turn.  When moving to certain tiles, the snails can leave a slime trail, which claims points at the end of the game. At the end of each turn, the players move the Saltmurai as well, to block the opponent's movement. 
When all five cards have been played, a round ends and the players note their points. The player with most points after three rounds is the winner.

Name: Cronk Chess
Description:
This is a mashup of chess and checkers.  Set up a normal chess game but with 8 checkers on each side where the 8 pawns normally go.

The chess pieces move, attack, and capture as they normally do, including castling.  The checkers move and capture (jump) as they normally do, diagonally.  Checkers that reach the other side get kinged.  If a checker can jump another checker or chess piece (or double or triple jump etc.), it must jump those pieces.  If your checker must jump your opponent's piece(s), but you're also in check, you must get out of check instead of jumping with the checker.

The game is won by checkmating the opponent's king either by an attack from a chess piece just like in chess, or threat of being jumped by a checker piece that the king can't avoid.

I invented this game and the first time I tried playing it (about 15 years ago), I didn't think it would be any fun, but I was pleasantly surprised.  It broke my brain as I mixed the two games in my head.  I had to play chess while making sure my chess pieces weren't lined up in such a way that they could get double jumped!  I also liked the fact that I could force moves on my opponent by placing pieces in position to be jumped by one of their checkers.  Let me know if you find any rule collisions that I have missed.

—description from the designer

Name: Indian Knaves
Description:
Rules for two players:

Use one deck of normal face cards.  Remove the jokers.  No table talk.  Trick-taking game like rook, but number of cards won matters rather than certain cards having points.

One player is the dealer.  The other player is the trump caller.  The dealer shuffles the deck and the other player cuts the deck.

The dealer deals 5 cards in a row face down to the trump caller.

The trump caller looks at their cards privately and chooses a trump suit based on just those 5 cards.

Once trump is called, the dealer then deals 5 cards face down to himself.  (The 5 cards dealt to each player will be part of their hand.)

The dealer then deals 8 face down cards in front of each player that nobody can look at.

The dealer then deals 8 face up cards on top of the face down cards that everyone can see.  (One face up card on top of each face down card.)

The dealer then deals 3 cards in a row to the trump caller's hand, then 3 cards in a row into his own hand.

The dealer then deals 2 cards in a row to the trump caller's hand, then 2 cards in a row into his own hand.

There should now be:
    10 cards in each player's hand that only the player holding them can see
    8 cards in front of each player that are face down that neither player has seen
    8 cards right on top of the face-down cards in front of each player that all players can see
    That makes a total of 52 cards in play (the whole deck without jokers).

The trump caller starts the game by choosing a card from either their hand or from the face up cards in front of them.

The other player then plays a card and must follow suit.  Highest card number wins.  Aces are high.  If they cannot follow suit because they don't have that suit either in their hand or face up on the table, they can play anything they want.  Trump cards will take the trick in that case and other suits (non-trump and not following suit) lose - just like in Rook.

Whenever a face up card is played, the face down card below it must immediately be turned over and it becomes part of the cards that can be played in subsequent tricks.

Whoever takes that trick keeps those cards and puts them aside and then leads the next trick.

The round ends when all cards in hands, face up, and face down have been played and all tricks taken.

The winner is the player that got the most tricks (most cards).  In the case of a tie, the dealer wins since the trump caller has a slight advantage and must take more than half of the cards to win.

To play another round, swap who is dealer and trump caller between each round played.  Choose a number of rounds to be won to win the overall game.

Strategy ideas

The game is similar to Rook, but it splits your hand into three parts:
    your hand - which only you see
    face down cards - which nobody sees
    face up cards - which everyone sees

One example of using this knowledge is that if a player doesn't follow suit and plays a face up card which then reveals a face down card that is the suit that was just led, then you know that's the only card of that suit they have and so they must play it if you lead that suit again.  There are many other strategies like this that can be used based on the global knowledge of face up cards.

Four players

The game could be modified for four players by using two decks and having the trump caller be the person to the left of the dealer and moving the dealer to the left each round.  Notice that there will be two of each card in such a game.

Three players

Just like four players but you could either use one deck and reduce the number of hand cards, face down cards, and face up cards or use two decks and increase the number of cards used for each player.
    one deck
        hand cards: 4 at the start, then 2 then 1 (instead of 5, 3, and 2)
        face down cards: 5
        face up cards: 5
        You'll have 1 card leftover.
    two decks (just double the numbers above - might be too much?)
        hand cards: 8 at the start, then 4, then 2
        face down cards: 10
        face up cards: 10
        You'll have 2 cards leftover.

Other notes

This is a combination of two games: one is a game from India who played it with his grandmother, the other is knaves.

It's apparently similar to the ancient card game "Whist", which is where the card game "Bridge" apparently came from and Rook is also similar in some ways.

We've actually played a three-player variant of Rook making the fourth dummy hand split as face down and face up and the dummy's partner plays from the face up cards - kind of like bridge but with face down cards hidden.

—description from the designer

Name: 1868: Wyoming
Description: While an 18xx game at heart, this game is designed to reflect both Wyoming’s core railroad history, and the effects of the coal and oil industry on its towns and cities. The gameplay is driven by the railroads which formed the territory and later the state. The boom-and-bust cycle directly impacts the towns and cities of the state and therefore the revenue of the railroads. Coal and Oil Companies in this game do not necessarily represent coal or oil discoveries, but instead represent investment for development in the area – indirect drivers of revenue. The map is reflective of the immense emptiness and its widely varied and rugged terrain.

Name: Dywizjon 303
Description: Each of the participants of the game becomes a pilot of Squadron 303. While circling the territory designated on the board, all pilots try to get a certain number of tokens as quickly as possible by accurately shooting in air combat or by knocking down enemy bombers. However, each pilot must be careful not to get hit himself. Knowing the history of Squadron 303 and the Battle of Britain (which can be found in the booklet attached to the game), players can earn additional tokens by answering the questions on the drawn cards. After collecting the appropriate number of tokens, you must still safely return to the base. Whoever does it first is the winner.

Name: Wer baut zuerst sein Haus?
Description:
The players have one pawn each, to move around the game board. Movement is determined by a die. After each complete round around the board the player gets a building piece to build his house (a foundation, 4 walls and a roof). If a pawn get on a space already occupied by another pawn , the one who arrived first gets thrown out and has to start the round anew. On the numbered spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

The first player to complete his house wins the game.

—user summary

Name: Dziennik: Zagadkowa podróż
Description:
Go with Karolina, Kazik and the otter Jacinta to search for their missing friend. Thanks to the clues of Zagadroid, you will travel together through 7 chapters in all corners of the world and solve over 40 puzzles.
 Especially with children and adolescents in mind, the authors created a completely new mechanism for reading answers and prompts. Thanks to this, when solving puzzles, we do not have to use the help of smartphones or computers, as we did in Journal 29: Interactive Book Game or Trip 1907: Interactive Escape the Book Game!

Name: 1815, Scum of the Earth: Give Me Night
Description:
Prussian Army Expansion, that consists of 57 Prussia-themed cards. 
You will have an opportunity to substitute British army with Prussians or add Prussian army forces to play with British player against two French players according with the special multiplayer rules.

Name: Samsara
Description: Dexterity game in which marbles are placed in holes of a "giant wheel", which thereby changes its center of gravity and causes marbles to fall out. A metal marble particularly unbalances the wheel. The player to place all his marbles in the wheel wins the game.

Name: Codicod
Description: Player get a hand of five letter tiles and place them on a 8x8 grid to form words and earn points. The letters that are at play can be rotated to form other letters (e.g H is I rotated 90 degrees), and consequently other words. Points are used to purchase new tiles. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

Name: Papaya Monkey
Description:
Papaya Monkey is a competitive, medium light weight, card game from Cayro the Games. Children will have a lot of fun and adults will enjoy the challenge behind.

The jungle is growing non-stop and the monkeys try to hog and gobble as many papayas as possible. But watch out! There are many wild animals lurking.

Each player will place a piece of jungle, place or move his monkeys and also push others with secret attacks. The purpose is to be the player who gets the most papayas with his monkey team  at the end of the game. Reward cards also have extra papayas.

Name: Resistenza!
Description:
In September 1943, by virtue of the the Armistice of Cassibile, the Kingdom of Italy officially surrenders to the Allies. Nazi Germany swiftly responds by occupying the northern part of its former ally, by disarming its army (Operation Achse), and by freeing and reinstating Mussolini as the leader of the fascist Italian Social Republic puppet state. Several elements of the dissolved Regio Esercito refuse to comply, flee to the Alpine and Apennine foothills, and take up arms against the nazifascist occupation. Like in most other German-occupied European countries, they will soon be joined by anti-fascists and rebels, giving rise to the first formations of the Italian partisan resistance warfare, which will quickly reorganise themselves as "brigades" and oppose the fascist regime until the liberation of April 1945.

In the summer of 1944, after the breaching of the Gustav Line and the liberation of Rome, a new frontline is established along the northern ranges of the Apennines, from the Adriatic to the Tyrrhenian sea. The so called "Gothic Line" will stand until the end of the war. During these dramatic months, the areas around  the Gothic line will witness some of the most ferocious reprisals of the European war, often involving directly the civilian population.

Resistenza! is a cooperative boardgame that relates the partisan struggles in and around the small valley of Lunigiana, tucked in between the Apennines and Alpi Apuane in the western-most portion of the Gothic line, from the standpoint of the partisan brigades.

The game is tactical in nature, reflecting the fluidity of guerilla warfare, although several game decisions have broader, strategic consequences. The brigades must ambush convoys along the valley's main communication lines, thwart nazifascist reprisals against civilians and participate in the final liberation battles. Attacks are resolved by committing combat cards against enemy tiles of unknown value (unless scouted by previous reconnaissance). Materiel airdrops are also represented, through the drop of a die on the game map. The design focus is on evocation over simulation, implying a certain degree of abstraction. A semi-cooperative and a simplified version of the game are also included, as well as a booklet of historical and design notes.

The proceeds from the game will support the activities of Archivi della Resistenza and the running of the Audiovisual Museum of the Resistance (Fosdinovo, MS, Italy) .

—description from the designer

Name: 英雄对决 (Hero Battle): Marvel
Description:
A trading card game published by Chinese collectible card publisher Kayou.
In this game, players can use heros from Ultraman Universe or Marvel Universe to fight with the opponent.
At the start of the game, each player draw 9 cards and set 5 of them on the field, other 4 cards are their hand. In each turn, player should choose a card on the field to fight the opponent, the player who has 5 heroes defeated will lose the game.

Name: Objective: Survive
Description:
This print and play board game is a game where you, the player's plane has crashlanded somewhere in the north Canadian wilderness. You are its only survivor. Your objective is to survive the four weeks it takes for rescue crews to find you.
In order to accomplish this, you must learn to find and manage Food, Water, Wood, and, the most valuable resource, your own health. As the weeks progress the days will get progressively tougher. It is up to you to ensure your own survival in this harsh wilderness.

Name: ドルフィンスナップ (Dolphin Snap)
Description:
ãƒ‰ãƒ«ãƒ•ã‚£ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒŠãƒƒãƒ— (Dolphin Snap) is a game from Japan in which players try to compose photos of marine life in an aquarium. The game includes a picture frame and a tripod. Cutouts of dolphins and whales are assembled on vertical stands and process around through dice rolls. Players are trying to get attractive groupings of dolphins in frame at the right time to get their photo. The best composed shots win the most points.

The game has a long blue cord which is placed as a loop on the table. The frame is set up in front of this, and a blue background is put to the rear. Players then throw a number of blue dice into the loop. These determine which marine animals appear. The number and types of dolphins are limited and will not appear all the time. The cutouts are clipped at different levels to blue poles, and these are stuck to small platforms which go alongside the corresponding dice. Looking through the frame, the players can see some creatures in shot, but not all of them. In this way, players compose a shifting three dimensional diorama of sea life passing the frame of the camera.

Players have to chose when to take a good photo. Should they get a quick snap, or wait a bit in case a more interesting creature swims by. Will the enormous whale shark appear at the back? If the dolphins move on, will the players regret the missed chance to get a good picture?

When a player has taken their photo and scored points for it, the next player rolls the dice and continues.

Whilst being a competitive game, the designer's intention is to engage the players in a contemplative experience as they consider their place in the world. The game can be played just as well by a solo player.
user summary

Name: Little Nutters: The Card Game
Description:
A card game where memory, strategy, and luck are needed as you maneuver around challenges presented both by your fellow players and randomly by the game itself. Little Nutters is a turn-based game where you take on the persona of a squirrel trying to uncover their buried nuts through the various patches on the playing field. Be the first to find all of your nuts before your opponents, but beware of rapid kittens, quack attacks, and ninja beavers. The dangers are very real in Little Nutters.

One by one, players take turns searching or digging through 27 randomly shuffled patches of 4 cards. The ultimate goal is to uncover a nut within these patches, but along the way players may find defense cards to bolster their hand or obstacles or animal attacks to possibly hinder their turn. Watch out for other players too as they can play trouble cards during their turn to weaken your hand or bust-a-nut cards to try and steal one of your hard earned prizes.

Set in a whimsical environment with fantastic cartoon-ish artwork, Little Nutters is a perfect party game with a quick  and easy set-up and rules.

—description from the publisher

Name: Fair Isle 40
Description:
A knitting card game for 1-2 players in which players compete to knit the best FAIR ISLE PATTERN. Players earn points by completing rows, matching motifs and unlocking bonuses.

The Fair Isle deck is made of cards that display simple two-colour knitting motifs (diamonds, crosses, etc).  Players build hands of motif cards which are then played in rows to create a knitting pattern. Each row is just 3 cards long, and a completed Fair Isle pattern is just 4 rows high (12 cards in tital).

There are also 8 pattern bonus cards (yellow) that provide certain conditions to score bonuses on that row (for instance, knitting a ‘green row’ at the right time can earn you an extra 20 points).

Players score points for :

     knitting a complete row
     repeating patterns in a row
     finishing 4 rows first
     alternating stripes of colour
     unlocking row Pattern Bonuses


SETUP

Each player is dealt 3 cards. The remaining deck forms a Draw Pile between the players, with the top two cards placed face up by the draw pile.

4 Pattern Bonus cards are also chosen and placed face up, one above the other, in a column between the players. The bottom card is ‘row 1’ - the top card is ‘row 4’.

PLAY

On their turn, a player can take ONE of the following FOUR actions:


     PICK UP  -   either:  1 x face up Fair Isle card  or:  2 x face down cards (Draw Pile)
     KNIT  - Place ANY NUMBER of cards from your hand into your pattern.
     UNRAVEL - Take any number of ‘knitted’ cards back to your hand.
     DISCARD - Discard your entire hand.


END OF TURN

At the end of their turn, a player will either DRAW BACK UP to 3 (if less than 3 cards are in their hand) or DISCARD DOWN to 5 (if they have more than 5 cards left in hand:)

GAME END

The game ends when one player completes their Fair Isle pattern first, receiving a bonus 40 points. The other player can take one more turn before the final scores are then tallied up.

—description from the designer

Name: Hedgehog Roll & Friends
Description:
Hedgehog throws a party and invites his forest friends: owls, squirrel, moose, bear and boar. The tables are already served and everything is ready for the guests. Oh, wait – the hedgehog has forgotten to decorate his famous cake! But how can the hedgehog leave the house unattended if the fox is making its way to steal the tasty treats? Luckily, his friends are always ready to help!

Bring hedgehog home faster than the fox reaches it and steals the cake! First, you need to define a friend who will help the hedgehog this round and gather goods. Throw fuzzy ball (hedgehog) into the box with velcro tokens with friends’ portraits. Got a moose? Roll the hedgehog down from the moose slide and collect goods stuck on the ball! A bear decided to help? It’s time for a catapult! Each friend has its special ability. 
Next, move the hedgehog. For each collected nut/ berry/wheat, you can move your hedgehog to an adjacent spot with this goodie. 
Finally, it’s time for a fox to move one step closer to the hedgehog’s house.

The hedgehog (and all the players as well) wins as soon as the hedgehog reaches the house. The hedgehog loses the game if the fox reaches the house first.

—description from the publisher

Name: 18Rhine
Description:
Set in the Rhine River valley, this is much like 18USA and the 1817 branch of 18xx, but has no short shares.

The loans are still present, but have fixed interest each OR, and if the company cannot pay, the company's owner owes 2x what the company would have paid.

Name: Pis a Pis
Description:
Pis a Pis, may the neighborhood coexistence not end with you!
The first board game of the commune, with ecological, inclusive and linguistic awareness.

A block of flats has just been built and your real estate company owns half of the building. You have to decide who to rent them to, but it’s not that easy. Will you be able to have your flats occupied before your opponent?

Pis a Pis is a card game for two people from 8 years and lasting approximately 10 minutes. It consists of 63 cards, divided into 3-color floors (blue, red, and yellow), as well as gray cards with effects.

The aim of the game is to place flats playing your cards in your part of the building until you fill the 6 floors.

In each turn you can play a card or discard a card. Then you take one card from the deck (you always have to have three cards on your hand).

If you fill the 6 floors before your opponent, you win!

—description from the publisher (translated)

Pis a Pis, que la convivència veïnal no acabi amb tu! 
El primer joc de taula de lacomuna, amb consciència ecològica, inclusiva i lingüística.

S’acaba de construir un bloc de pisos i la teva immobiliària té en propietat la meitat de l’edifici. Has de decidir a qui llogar-los, però no és tan fàcil. Aconseguiràs tenir els teus pisos ocupats abans que l’oponent?

Pis a Pis és un joc de cartes per a dues persones a partir de 8 anys i amb una durada aproximada de 10 minuts.

Amb una mecànica senzilla i divertida, les partides de Pis a Pis són dinàmiques i ràpides, ideals per jugar amb la família i les amistats durant les llargues nits d’hivern. Se’ns acut encara un altre escenari… Si la persona que viu a l’altra banda de l’escala et genera una passió incontrolable, ja no cal que vagis a demanar-li sucre; proposa-li jugar a Pis a Pis i trenca el gel!

Pis a Pis consta de 63 cartes, dividides en pisos de 3 colors (blau, vermell i groc), i també cartes de color gris amb efectes.
L’objectiu de Pis a Pis és col·locar pisos a la teva part de l’edifici fins a omplir les 6 plantes abans que la immobiliària oponent.

—description from the publisher

Name: 零次元（Dimension Zero）
Description:
A trading card game using many famous animes, such as naruto, bleach, one piece.
The game like duel masters, players can use any card as energy and use energy to play cards. Attack player use characters to attack and defence player can choose to block or take damage. Player takes 6 damage will lose the game.

Name: Chronicles of Drunagor: Age of Darkness – Apocalypse
Description:
Chronicles of Drunagor - Age of Darkness Apocalypse is a massive expansion that brings another chapter in Daren's fight against Darkness. Through 16 adventures that present new mechanics and level structures, unravel Drunagor's culture and mythology in an enhanced Campaign development experience where your choices will change the adventures you will face and the conclusion of your narrative.

—description from the publisher

Name: Sushi-Trick
Description: This is a trick-taking game with the theme of sushi competition ((The mini-game called trick is repeated until the cards are exhausted, and the winner is determined for each mini-game. The person with the most winning tricks wins).

Name: こねこのままで (Koneko No Mama De)
Description:
ã“ã­ã“ã®ã¾ã¾ã§ is a trick-taking type card game that can be enjoyed by 3 to 6 people.
 Players are cat lovers, each with their own cat.
At first, it's a small and cute kitten, but if you pick up the card with a trick, your body will grow!
Let's put out the card well so that the cat does not grow out!

Name: ティモ (Timo)
Description:
ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ¢ (Timo) is a game from Japan that mimics the videogame Tetris.

The game has a lot of wooden T shapes and two d6 dice and some components to aid play; a base plate, a measuring block and scoring sticks.

The dice are different. One shows the T shape but with a line in different places to show its orientation to the base. The other dice shows 1,1,1,1,2,3.

The rules allow two games, one to play Tetris and one for a balancing game. With the Tetris game, players take turns to roll the dice and place the shapes in a vertical stack, no wider than the base plate.
user summary

Name: Numbalee
Description:
Fast-thinking, 13 fun compact games of chance and skill for all the Family to improve players skills in addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. Players are encouraged to verbally explain their sum, and challenge errors.

Numbalee can be played anywhere with a table or flat surface. It is packaged in a sturdy canvas bag making it easy to travel with and take on holiday.

Name: Tumble Tumble
Description:
Tumble Tumble is a wooden block stacking board game requiring skill, strategy and dexterity. The aim of the game centres around building a stack of wooden blocks to create an unstable tower and making sure you dont make it TUMBLE TUMBLE. If you cause the tower to TUMBLE TUMBLE you lose the game. Players need to assess tilt angles, leverage, surface friction, weight and positioning and possess manual dexterity skills. The game has simple rules and a short playtime of under 15 minutes. It can be played from 1 to 5 players and is ideal for ages 6 and upwards. Game contains 60 hardwood blocks,  base board and instructions.

—description from the publisher

Name: かけるかな？ (Kakeru ka na?)
Description:
ã‹ã‘ã‚‹ã‹ãªï¼Ÿ (Kakeru ka na?) is a communication game from Japan. "Do you call it?" was produced in a sealed paper bag, and contains 50 picture cards, and a block of notepaper and 6 pencils.

Players take turns to be the explainer. The explainer takes one of the picture cards in secret and explains what the image is. The other players draw their idea of the shape based upon the description. Once each player has done, they show their drawings and compare them with the picture card. They decide who got closer to the image on the picture card.

If they agree the drawing was close enough to the picture card, the explainer gets 5pts, the drawer gets 3pts, and the other players get 1pt each.

Players take turns to be the explainer. When everyone has been explainer at least once, the scores are totalled up. The player with the most points wins.

The designer suggest ways to make it easier or harder to explain. The explainer should start with describing what the largest part of the image is. For an easier game, allow players to ask questions, let the explainer use their hands, players can use an eraser. To make the game harder, allow only one question each, words only, no eraser. The hardest method limits the players to only 5 minutes and no questions or eraser.

The designer suggests you can draw your own new shapes on the backs of the picture cards, or use a computer (the designer used Paint to make the game). Or if you tire of the game, use the cards as coasters for your drinks!
user summary

Name: LAN ZIN  CARD GAME
Description:
As a tactician amid the chaos of the warring states period, deploy Samurai you've enlisted and make battle formations with them.

Completing formations boosts Morale and Rewards. As your Morale rises higher, you can summon more soldiers, also call your support unit and strategists. Even with samurai soldiers sent by others, win as many Rewards as possible and lead your military to victory.

By placing Samurai cards with the same crest or number in a specific arrangement, players can complete a formation. Each completed formation provides you with Morale and Rewards. Morale, your military spirit, enables you to enlist more soldiers and strategists. It also allows you to acquire one row or column that can potentially provide Rewards according to the number of cards placed at the end of the game.

Earning more Rewards than the other players is the main objective of this game.

Name: Under Falling Skies: Prague City Promo Tile
Description:
Additional city tile released as a promo in CZ, EN, DE, FR, ES, PL.

				
				
					Prague (B/A)Blue side (research 3)

"Once per round, when you would shoot down a ship, you can instead shoot down a different ship that is higher in the sky. It doesn't need to be on an explosion space."

Red side (research 2)

"Whenever you would shoot down a ship, you can instead shoot down a different ship on the same sky tile or higher. It doesn't need to be on an explosion space."

Name: Beyond the Sun: Sagittarius A and Beta Colony Promo Cards
Description:
Beyond the Sun: Sagittarius A and Beta Colony is a set of two promotional cards that can be added to Beyond the Sun. Here's what these cards do:


    Sagittarius A System card: Ship may never leave this System for any reason (including ships that are passing through). When colonized, all ships on this System (of any faction) are removed from the game.



    Beta Colony Technology card: Pay two ore and return two population to colonize a System card. Get a reward based on the value of the highest ship that is returned to your Faction mat.


Was also available as part of the rewards for backing Game Boy Geek 2021 Kickstarter campaign.

Name: High Noon Showdown
Description:
Tension fills the air... It is high noon and all the town folk have prepared themselves to face off in the center of town. Who will be faster? Who will win? It is time for the High Noon Showdown!

In High Noon Showdown, you will be acting, and reacting, in a rapid race to build up an attack (or to defend yourself) over multiple rounds. You and every other player are gunning for each other to reduce your enemies’ Life Points to 0, eliminating them from the game. Don't forget about your unique character abilities to turn the odds of winning in your favor as you try to outdraw your opponents. Will you be the last one standing and declare victory, or will you fall to the lawlessness of the west? The choice is yours. Now DRAW!!!

—description from the publisher

Name: Canvas: Reflections – Deluxe Edition
Description:
Paint from a new perspective! In Canvas: Reflections, the artistic puzzle has a new layer -- Mirror Cards! These reversible cards add deeper strategy, and also give you increased flexibility to string together combinations of Elements. Additionally, the new board offers a wider selection of Art Cards that allows you to better plan ahead and presents more choices even when running low on Inspiration Tokens.

Also features:
Gold Bonus Ribbons - Grab a Gold Bonus Ribbon for lining up a specific Element next to a Gold Bonus icon.

New Scoring Cards for puzzling new challenges and added replayability.

The Deluxe Edition includes:

+  10 More Reversible Transparent Cards

+ 5 Signature Style Cards

+  2 Ribbon Pins

+ 26 Expansion Wood Tokens

This edition will not be available in retail. It will only be sold through Kickstarter!

Name: 黄色の天球 (Kiiro no Tenkyu)
Description:
é»„è‰²ã®å¤©çƒ (Kiiro no Tenkyu) is a memo deduction game from Japan. A series of murders take place in a mountain villa. The players try to resolve who is the murderer by working out who was with the victims. It is possible that one of the players is the killer or an non-player character (NPC).

The villa is represented in the game by an eight-sided cube. Each side has a transparent window and internal walls with doorways. The player pieces are put inside the cube and during the game it is turned about. The pieces move around, some to one room, some to another.

As players are moved around, they can collect evidence cards from a corresponding plan of the villa. Each player has alibi cards face down in front of them that they can look at. By meeting up in different rooms, a player can see cards held by other players or NPCs.

A murder takes place at 9pm, and each turn is ten minutes in the game. On the hour, another murder, then a third until the game ends at midnight.

The players must try to deduce who is committing the murders and with what weapon, where and when. As the game progresses, players can make their claim by passing and becoming the start player. They score points if they identify correctly the hidden info for each crime.

Finding the murder weapon in the room is very hard but possible too.

At the end of the game, the player with the most points is the winner.
user summary

Name: Llama Farmer
Description:
Light-strategy tabletop card game. Each player takes the role of a mountain Llama Farmer trying to make the most money ('Bucks') selling llama-wool rugs.

Players start with their own small herd of randomised primary coloured llama cards. Each turn players expand, shear, weave or sell.
Expanding adds new primary coloured llamas, or expands the llama 'family-tree' making more complex colours and patterns available.
Shearing produces wool, either unpredictably with a repeatable 'light shear' based on selected dice and numbers on the llama cards producing wool for any farmer or a one-shot 'close shave' which guarantees wool at the cost of a chilly looking llama!
Weaving combines wools into new colours or rugs and selling trades rugs for bucks in the markets. High-fashion markets want specific rugs and pay well, but a general market will buy any rug cheaply.

The game ends when all the high-fashion markets close, and the farmer with the most bucks wins.

Strategy choice comes from choosing the right rugs and llamas to go for, balancing expanding and shearing and knowing when to apply a close shave.

—description from the publisher

Name: Mickey Mouse's Pizza Party Game
Description:
Players must travel along the board collecting pizzas.  The first one to get to the end of the board with 3 pizzas wins.

—user summary

Name: Magna Acies! Armies & Battles: Punic and Macedonian Wars
Description:
This booklet is the first in a series, entitled Armies and Battles, accompanying MAGNA ACIES! "battle size" rules for 3D wargames for the Ancient age (without the rules, therefore, this booklet serves you little purpose).

We decided to start from the Punic Wars and the Macedonian Wars because these were probably, from a tactical point of view, the most interesting conflicts of Antiquity, which marked (together with Alexander's campaigns) new reference models for Military Art.

During these conflicts, the Romans had to abandon the primitive concept of the simple "attack on the center" to worry about the wings as well, while the phalanx ceased to be the most successful formation of Antiquity: fundamental themes, as you can well understand, decisive for 15 subsequent centuries and even beyond.

This booklet consists essentially of three elements:

     three "Quickstart Scenarios" (with attached game tables),
     fifteen "Army Lists" (always with attached game tables) and
     six "Battle Maps"


—description from the publisher

Name: Zombicide (2nd Edition): Nico
Description:
Nico is a promotional character (miniature plus character card) for Zombicide 2nd Edition.

A master of wielding dual katanas.

Name: BattleTech: Alpha Strike – Succession Wars Cards
Description:
Alpha Strike is BattleTech’s fast-playing game of armored combat. Alpha Strike Succession Wars Cards contains the ‘Mech Units that survived centuries of warfare across the Inner Sphere. Fullcolor, poker sized, and laminated for dry-erase use, you just need miniatures and dice and you’ll be battling for control of mankind’s tenuous future.

     98 double-sided, dry-erase cards expand players’ available ‘Mech roster.
     10 double-sided combat command cards include special rules to play units of renown from BattleTech lore.
     Includes all the ‘Mechs from Technical Readout: Succession Wars

Name: Making the Rounds: A Micro Nursing Game
Description:
You have 2 shifts to try and treat all of your patients in your hall by monitoring, evaluating, medicating, taking samples to the lab, and even treating Code: Blues. Each patient will have 3 needs you will have to meet with your action cards. Drawing action cards will let you decide where you should start and placing your nurse meeple there and trying to pull the right combo to complete the task at hand. If you succeed, you can flip the patient card over, if you don’t succeed, you turn the card sideways and on your next shift you can try to treat that patient again. If after 2 shifts you only have 1 patient not succeeded then you will have 1 over time shift to treat that patient.

—description from the publisher

Name: BattleTech: Alpha Strike – Clan Invasion Cards
Description:
Alpha Strike is BattleTech’s fast-playing game of armored combat. Alpha Strike Clan Invasion Cards contains the ‘Mech Units that sprung from the distant Periphery to terrorize the Inner Sphere and ‘Mechs designed to repel them. Full-color, poker sized, and laminated for dry-erase use, you just need miniatures and dice and you’ll be battling for control of mankind’s tenuous future.

     98 double-sided, dry-erase cards expand players’ available ‘Mech roster.
     10 double-sided combat command cards include special rules to play units of renown from BattleTech lore.
     Includes all the ‘Mechs from Technical Readout: Clan Invasion

Name: Mage War
Description:
Mage War is a FREE trading card game where you construct your own cards and make decks to battle other players. It is a game of strategy with a focus on balanced mechanics that put opponents on equal footing. (No need to worry about an opponent having an advantage over you because they spent more money to build their deck.) The rules lay out all the guidelines for designing and creating your own cards and decks as well as how to play. The limits of your power are the limits of your own imagination! Craft your own cards and build your own strategy around your own play style and pit your ideas against your friends.

—description from the designer

Name: Szybkie bańki
Description: The game objective is to find the right card faster than your opponents. The player who has the most cards at the end will win.

Name: Hot Wheels. Вызов принят!
Description: Children's racing game where players upgrade their cars and try to win trophies during the 3-laps' drive. The one who gets the most points in the end wins.

Name: А у моего бати руки-бензопилы
Description:
A comic-strategic game in which the participants "measure up" the coolness of their dad. They are credited with the properties of heroes in games, comics and films. Collect combinations and monitor the progress of opponents. The game combines simple and strategic gameplay with a fun design full of references to popular games and films from the 90s and 2000s.

Players use Honor cards to "pimp" their dad, dressing him in armor and presenting him with various kinds of artifacts that refer to popular games, films and comics. And opponents' dads can be thrown with negative discouraging cards. Reaction cards allow you to fend off opponents or strengthen your actions, and Freak cards are the most powerful arguments in the fight against other players. For each set they collect, players receive Honorable Points and new powerful cards.

On his turn, a player can play from 1 to 2 cards. Before playing an Honor card, the player must say loudly and clearly: "And my / your daddy ..." - and then the text from the card. Otherwise, the card will not work and will be discarded.

English version of title: And my daddy has chainsaw hands....

Play continues until "The End" card is reached and points are totaled.  The player with the most points wins.

Name: It's Alive!: Monster-Making Mayhem
Description:
Be the first to assemble a monster from different body parts and bring it to life!

A monster must have the following body parts: A head, a torso, a left arm, a right arm, a left leg and a right leg.

Use power cards to improve your chances or to hinder your opponents! This is where the game really comes to life. From creating monsters with different background colours to stealing cards from your opponents or destroying their power cards, you'll find many fiendish ways to give yourself an advantage - but beware, your opponents will be trying to play the same tricks on you!

—description from the publisher

Name: Rat Queens: To the Slaughter
Description:
Forge friendships and find your family as you take on the role of the rat queens in Rat Queens: To the Slaughter. Choose from four rat queens, each with asymmetric and unique playstyles, in order to save Palisade from total destruction. Power up your queen with new abilities and friendship as you take on hordes of monsters. Each queen comes packed with upgradeable abilities you have to spend gold to learn, allowing you to customize your queen differently each game to fit what the party needs!

Players spend the first half of the game defeating monsters to earn rewards to upgrade their ability deck and stats in order to prepare for the Big Bad hiding in the wake. The more monsters you defeat, the more powerful you become and the more time you have before the Big Bad arrives, with that enemy being determined by which monsters escape. Combat is a simplified version of RPG-style combat with easy-to-learn dice checks for attacks and abilities.

From the first sip to the last drop. Sisters. Warriors. Queens. Friends to the very end.

—description from the publisher

Name: Poop Poop
Description:
Poop Poop is a collection set card game for children.

The children are farmers that have to preparing to fertilize their fields. They need the help of farm animals. Each animals have to eat and drink to poop. Collecting all poop is needed to win.

Each player have five cards, when the player has at same time an animal, a water and food can discard them and take the corresponding poop.

There are also some special cards to stole poop, or change poop with other players.

—user summary

Name: アザトース (Azathoth)
Description:
ã‚¢ã‚¶ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¹ (Azathoth) is a card game from Japan mixing anime and Cthulhu themes. A variation on Old Maid, players are trying to form up pairs of cards to empty their hands. Some of the cards are for the Old Gods. The cards have text on them, and the Old Gods have special abilities. Players must always keep Old Gods cards in their hand (they start with one), and if they are found without one, they draw a penalty.

The main cards are anime, with letters of the alphabet, such that a player asks another for an A or a B and so on. Making up sets lets the player discard them.

The special abilities of the Old Gods restrict how those cards might be played.

Like many Loserdogs games, the game is sold in a large ziplocked bag with minimal production. The cardstock is thin but playable.
user summary

Name: Hero Realms: Imperial Justice Promo Card
Description:
Part of the Game Trade Magazine (GTM) May 2021 issue 255 but only for copies sold in stores in the USA. It will also later be available to buy from different sources, like conventions.

Name: Imperial Justice
Faction: Imperial
Gold Cost: 4
Card Type: Action
Card Text: Add 6 to your combat pool, Imperial Ally Ability: Draw a card for each opposing champion you stunned this turn.

Name: Castle Panic: Deluxe Collection
Description:
The Castle Panic Deluxe Collection is the long-awaited, ultimate, deluxe edition of Castle Panic and all of it's expansions. This giant box contains 5 games in their limited edition, deluxe versions including: Castle Panic, The Wizard's Tower, The Dark Titan, Engines of War, and the brand new expansion Crowns and Quests.

Each game retains the same mechanics fans have loved for over a decade, but now feature deluxe upgraded components. Each game comes with all new art, plastic Walls, Towers, and castle pieces, plastic Monster minis that feature a unique spinning base to track damage, wooden Monster tokens, promo cards, a deluxe monster bag, playmat, and much more. This massive collection features 180 plastic pieces including 97 Monster miniatures!

Castle Panic is a cooperative game for 1 to 6 players where everyone is working together to defend the castle from monsters coming in from the forest. The players must make it through all 49 Monster tokens and have at least 1 tower still standing in order to win the game. If the monsters destroy all 6 towers, the game ends and the monsters win.

In The Wizard's Tower, a friendly wizard joins your forces, giving the players access to powerful magic spell cards. But the monster army returns, bigger, smarter, and faster than ever before.

In The Dark Titan, the ancient Titan, Agranok returns to lay siege to the castle. Agranok is proceeded by his Heralds and brings new monsters while the players get help from Support Tokens and the Cavalier.

Engines of War brings a whole new economy to the game where players can assign tasks to the Engineer and collectively pay Resource cards toward those tasks to build traps and weapons. Meanwhile the monsters press the attack with Siege Engines and new creatures.

The newest expansion, Crowns and Quests, introduces playable characters with unique powers. The players must attempt to complete challenging quests such as retrieving magical items, destroying cursed temples, and even teleporting the entire castle to safety all while fighting off the monster army.

This collection is the centerpiece to the Castle Panic Deluxe Collection Kickstarter and as such will not be available through retail distribution.

-description from publisher

Name: O Petróleo é nosso!
Description: In the early 1950s, Brazil was agitated by a campaign in favor of the nationalization of the oil industry. This game is based on this spirit: it is a simple game, the players spin the roulette wheel to transport their equipment to the drilling point. When they get there they automatically lose a round and start their progression through the houses corresponding to the land to be drilled. The winner is the first to reach the oil layer with an exact bid.

Name: The 実名報道 (The Jitsumeihodo)
Description:
The å®Ÿåå ±é“ (The Jitsumeihodo) is a game from Japan in which players identify famous people by their real names. In japan, Jitsumeihodo means 'real name reporting' and is the somewhat controversial practise of identify people in news coverage by their real names.

The game has a deck of 60 cards, 30 being the real names of people, and 30 showing a colour photo of the person. On the back of the photos is the same photo min B&W and a short text explaining what crime they were arrested for. For example, a popular comedian caught with cocaine, or a hit-and-run driver.

The 30 photo cards are shuffled and laid out randomly on the table, showing only the colour photo side. The deck of names is shuffled up and placed in the middle, so the first name can be read out.

Players try to match up the correct name to the face. However, this is difficult since the people are generally known by a public name, not by their real name.

The game can be played solitaire.

Like many Loserdogs games, the game is sold in a large ziplocked bag with minimal production. The cardstock is thin but playable.
user summary

Name: Taxi!: The "Drive as You Please" Traffic Game
Description:
In Taxi, you play the role of a taxi driver whose goal is to pick up passengers and deliver them to the airport. All the while, you have to obey the rules of the road. If you are in violation of the driving laws, then you can become targeted by the police.

Players control their taxi plus they control one police car. On your turn, roll two 6 sided dice. You assign one die to yourself and one to your police car. But you also have two optional methods for the roll:  you can assign both dice to your police car move, or you can take one of your dice, assign it to your taxi, and DOUBLE it. This represents speeding, which is a violation.

Whenever you break the law, you become vulnerable to being captured by other player's police cars. Other violations include: picking up passengers from the wrong side of the road and going down one way streets the wrong way. If you are caught by police for violating the law, you lose any passengers in your cab, you go to traffic court and pay hefty fines.

Game ends when there are no more passengers to pick up. The taxi driver with the most money wins the game and is obligated to look in a mirror and say "are you lookin at me?".

Name: Anno Domini 1666: Envoys of the High Porte – Janissaries Commoners Set
Description:
Soldiers of the elite 32nd orta boluk are among the few that were not influenced by the crisis spreading in the Janissary corps. They are devoted to their commander and religion, they have hing morale and are very difficult to force off the battlefield. Despite having firearms they usually use it to start the fight and then move on to close combat.

3 plastic miniatures
6 Character cards including three cards exclusive for this expansion: 2x Janissary Veteran and Janissary Odabasi
9 item cards

-description from publisher's website

Name: Anno Domini 1666: Bohun's Rebels – Moloitsy Commoners Set
Description:
Armed with sabres and arquebuses, moloitsy form the backbone of Cossack armies. They are proficient in close and ranged combat, but their true strengths are their senses and their quickness sharpened by the tough life in the Ukrainian steppes.

3 plastic miniatures 
6 Character cards including three cards exclusive for this expansion: 2x Moloiets Veteran and Desatnik
6 item cards

-description from publisher's website

Name: Fire Team Vietnam 2: Platoon Command
Description:
Fire Team Vietnam 2: Platoon Command is a Sub-Tactical level game of the Vietnam War, (1965-1975) that places each player in the role of a Company Commander, Sections and Squad of the U.S. Army or Allied Infantry Company against the forces of the National Liberation Front (NLF) (Viet Cong) and the North Vietnam Army (NVA) through various missions in the Vietnam.

These rules are an evolution of Fire Team Vietnam in a Version 2.0, with the aim of simplifying the rules so that it is easier and faster to play. 
But also to be able to play at 2 tactical levels with the corresponding rules and maps:

     Platoon Command = Sub-tactical , 1 hex = 5 meters, a Game Turn = 1 minute.

Name: Sunday League Football: A Board Game
Description:
Sunday League Football: A Board Game

Sunday League Football is a 2-4 player board game that brings all the heart-stopping drama and tension of the beautiful game right to your tabletop.

Take control of 1 of 4 unique amateur Football Clubs, each with different football philosophies, strengths and weaknesses and go for the title. During the week You'll need to build your squad, hire the right talent, choose a manager that complements your football style, learn the best tactics to carry out your game plan, and choose the starting eleven for each match.

During match days you go face to face against your rivals in intense, fast paced, and strategical matches. All decisions on the pitch come down to you. Managing your footballer resources, abilities and tactics in the best way possible added to the correct killer instinct to know when to strike is key to win.

Name: Bolt Action: Island Assault!
Description:
The battles of World War Two ravaged the entire world. 
Where the Band of Brothers starter set is very much concerned with the European Theatre in the wake of D-Day, this starter set shifts focus to the Pacific, pitting the United States Marine Corps against Japanese Island defenders in some of the most brutal and hard-fought battles of the War.

This starter set is focussed on the island-hopping campaigns enacted by the US to reclaim Japanese advances. 
Unlike the land war that raged in Europe, North Africa, and the Soviet Union, where vast armies of tanks and infantry could manoeuvre and fight over large tracts of open ground, the Pacific campaign was fought mostly on a series of relatively small islands, densely packed with jungles and protected by the sea. Each island had to be landed on, fought for, and the defenders rooted out of, individually.

Containing two opposing forces set amongst the many islands in the Pacific theatre, Island Assault! contains the Bolt Action 2nd edition rules as well as a scenario booklet guiding you through your first steps in the game.

Before long you’ll be adding to your new army and wreaking havoc on your foes be they fighting for Uncle Sam or the Emperor!

-description from the publisher

Name: KEPO: A Trait-Guessing Game
Description:
This is the big day of 2200!

A declaration of friendship between Planet Earth and Planet Kepo has been announced. Kepo aliens are so excited to study more about human traits. Hence, a big global event is held: A Game of Traits!

KEPO: A Game of Traits is a social party game that helps you reveal what people think about you. It has 3 different game
modes: 1 cooperative game & 2 competitive games. Players will be challenged to test their self-awareness and their ability to observe other players’ traits. With more than 400 traits and 3 difficulty levels to play, every single game will create a unique experience, filled with fun and new stories!

Name: 太陽と雨と虹  (Sun, Rain and Rainbow)
Description:
å¤ªé™½ã¨é›¨ã¨è™¹  ("Sun, Rain and Rainbow") is a card game. The cards consist of 36 cards in 7 color suits. Each suit has either a Sun or Rain(s). The color of suit can be recognized by the card back. The box comes with 4 games (with their rulebooks): "Sun Rummy”, "Rain Go Out", "Rainbow Trick" and "Weather Line".

"Lamii of the Sun"
Put the card in your place and make a role. By recombining the cards in the field and making good use of the special effects of the roles, you can create a role with a higher score and aim for a higher score by rising faster.

"Rain go out"
I will put out cards of the same color or continuous colors face down. I don't even know if it's "rainy" or "sunny". By reading and intuition, I will compete to get out of my hand as soon as possible.

"Rainbow Trick"
An anomalous trick-taking game where you control the points you earn. The winner will take the card by comparing the strength of the cards issued by everyone. Repeat this process, calculate the points you can get with the cards you get, and compete for points according to the points.

"Weather line"
Cards are put out alternately to make a four-row line. Compare the number of "own teams" for each row, and the one with the most will conquer that row. Compete for victory or defeat by the total number of conquered rows.

Name: DINGO
Description:
DINGO is a card game for the whole family, where you have to be the fastest creating words with the syllables that appear on the cards. But there are cheat cards you'll have to avoid!!.

The winner will be the player who previously runs out of cards in hand.

—description from the publisher (translated)

DINGO es un juego de cartas para toda la familia, donde tendrás que ser el más rápido creando palabras con las sílabas que aparecen en las cartas. Pero hay cartas trampas que tendrás que evitar!!.

El ganador será aquel jugador que antes se quede sin cartas en mano.

—description from the publisher

Name: Looping
Description:
Go on the funniest roller coaster and be the first to finish the ride!

Deal all the cards evenly between the players. They will keep them in their hands facing down.

The starting player is the player who has ridden a roller coaster most recently, otherwise the youngest player will be.

In turns, players play cards in the center of the table, one on top of other, in clockwise order. They must perform the actions corresponding to each played card correctly (see Game Cards). So that the first player who makes a mistake or otherwise, the last player who does it right, will draw 2 cards from the central deck as a penalty.

Regardless of the player who drew 2 cards, the game continues with the player who is next in turn.
